outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: free Pytorch course designed with fast.ai
apparently is a subject of the version of matplotlib

all_paragraphs: These days, due to certain circumstances, I found myself doing a free Pytorch course designed with fast.ai , the material on which this article is entirely based (lesson 2) and which has fascinated me, given the simplicity, usefulness, and solidity of these libraries.
In this article we will discover some tools of fast.ai for Pytorch, after completing its reading we will know:
The first thing I saw in the fast.ai online course is not explicit related to Pytorch or fast.ai, but to a way to create a dataset directly from the Google image search engine.
This technique is inspired by the work of Francisco Ingham and Jeremy Howard/Adrian Rosebrock¹.
We are going to create a data set with three classes of images based on photos of birds, wildcats, and airplanes.
We must assemble each one of the categories separately, to get the images of aircraft, we search in our browser, for example: “aircraft photography”.

To refine the search, we can use all the search engine tools, such as exclude unwanted elements in the name of the image (using -textToExclude, for example: -camera -airport) or filter only specific categories using the tag buttons.
For public use of the Dataset, you must filter in “Tools — Rights of use” and respect the copyright according to the case that applies.
Once we have in our browser the desired images, we will execute two Javascript sentences on the console.

“Press Ctrl-Shift-J in Windows/Linux and Cmd-Opt-J in Mac, and a small window the javascript ‘Console’ will appear. You will need to get the URLs of each of the images. Before running the following commands, you may want to disable adblocking extensions (uBlock, AdBlockPlus, etc.) in Chrome. Otherwise, the window.open() command doesn’t work. Then you can run the following commands: ”²

This code will start the download of a file, which we must rename as urls_[ClassName].csv. We have used as a convention for the name of the files the prefix ‘urls_’ and then the name of the class; this is very important for the functioning of the code that we will see later,
We repeat the operation of filtering images in the browser and downloading their URLs in a file renamed to CSV for each of the other three categories until you get:
If we take a look inside each of these files, we will see that they are simple files with the list of URLs of the filtered images

Once we have the list of URLs for each category in our CSV files, we’ll run the code to download the images and build our data set. In my case, I’ve created a ‘data/photos’ path, which is my base path. There I have placed the three CSV files of the categories and then we execute the code to create the subdirectories where the images will be download
To make the real download of the images we use
Then we execute code to verify that all downloaded images are correct, and that removes images that may be corrupt (delete=True)
To review the documentation for each of these statements you can run the doc() command, for example:

After having the images downloaded and verified in the path corresponding to each category, we can create a fast.ai DataBunch (similar DataFrame), put inside the tagged images, and start visualizing or working with them
And run the code to display a batch of 3 rows at random inside Dataset

For this exercise, we are going to use a convolutional neural net, in resnet34 format³. Within the models, there is a set of pre-defined net architectures, involving different structures and complexities⁴.
The resnet34 configuration is, in principle, sufficiently efficient and straightforward for the proposed scope
After the first training, we see that the net has not gone wrong at all, achieving an accuracy of 95% (error_rate = 0.045455), and the training time is perfect.
To be able to adjust this precision a little more, we have a method that graphs the behavior of the learning-rate parameter:

We see how the method searches through 20 pass the loss of the neural net for different learning rate values. Then we can graph them looking for the range that best suits and re-enter with that setting:

The left graph shows us the result of learning_rate in the neural net, and we must then look for the range of most significant learning, given between the beginning of the sustained decline, until the end of the fall and the start of the ascent.

This environment, marked by the bottom red bars in the graph on the right, gives us a start in the middle between 1e-⁶ and 1e-⁵, so we can roughly say that the beginning is nearly (1e-⁶ / 2); the final range is clearly at 1e-³
Let’s save this version of the model so we can go back over it

Although, in this case, the accuracy obtained could be sufficient, we will see two exciting tools to try to understand that circumstances have confused the training in addition to the classic “confusion matrix”*.
Let’s use now the ImageCleaner, a widget of fastai.widgets that will help us to delete or re-label those images of our model that are incorrect.

For the first cleaning training dataset tool, we need to find the path of the images that have the highest loss with the .from_toplosses method to locate the corresponding indexes and pass them to the ImageCleaner.

The widget does not delete the images of the corresponding path, but generates a new CSV file (cleaned.csv) with the list of the pictures “not for remove” and with the correct category in case, it has been reassigning
We create a new learn_cln model reading from the folders (from_folder), and we take the weights of the stage-2 saved in the previous stage.

Then separate the Dataset and the indices taken from the main training losses. With these objects, we invoke the ImageCleaner that will display on-screen the elements of confusion (from_toplosses) to allow us to eliminate them or reassign them to the correct class

The tool shows us in batch a set of confusing images and allows us to delete or re-classify them in the category box below each image. By clicking on next-batch, the file cleaned.csv re-label or removes them from its list. We must repeat this procedure until no more images in the widget.
The second tool for debugging our training images is the one that presents us with images that “could” be the same, to leave only one of them

In this case, the original Dataset used is clean enough not to present confusion by duplicate images. However, in the following example, we will see how it applies to the finding of similarities between images.
Here we have each directory with the original images, and the cleaned.CSV file contains the list of images that will remain and those that will be moved by a re-labeling

Here we must be careful handling code since it is necessary to regenerate the DataBunch (Data Frame with the images and their labels). Still, in this case, we are going to indicate that the origin is “from_csv” (in the previous example, it was “from_folder”).
By re-training the model, you reach 100% accuracy without finding confusing values and without error_rate on the training model. Great!
So far, we have worked a classification model of images using “resnet34” on a dataset created by us from Google.
For article purposes, conditions are sufficient to illustrate the power of machine learning, visualization, and cleaning dataset tools.

A real case has been raised recently, consists of taking the images attached to the tickets of users who report needs on ERP software. The objective was to classify these images in the following categories: ‘reports,’ ‘errors,’ ‘screen,’ ‘tickets.’
Images were hosted on a server, below the ‘attach’ path, in subdirectories numbered with the ID of the user reporting the error, message, or need.
We used the following Python code to unify the images in a directory, and from there, the client “tagged” them separating in the folders corresponding to each category.

Once the files were unifying, an application was install so that the client could label them in their corresponding folders, and the same training and toning procedure was applied, obtaining the following results:
We close initial accuracy (before ImageCleaner) of just over 85%.
Here we see a clear example of the ImageCleaner with the search for similar, which we could not see in the previous model.

After the training dataset cleaning and relabeling of the confusing cases, we retake the dataBuch from the cleaned.csv, and when re-training the model, taking as data source the clean base, we obtain a 100% accuracy again.

Following the content of lesson 2 of the fast.ai course, and in order not to waste excellent content that appears there, we are going to spread it because, on many occasions, it is difficult for people away from programming, imagine how to deploy a model.
First, let’s see how the model behaves predicting from our working environment in the Jupyter Notebook

This command creates a file called “export.pkl” in the working directory, which contains everything necessary for the deploy of the model (weights, metadata of the classes, and transformations or normalizations used).
Now that we have to take a look of 00000022.jpg, we test the model:
And the result, of course, is the category birds!
Now, let’s orient ourselves about putting the model into production. For that, we are his framework is restrictive on Python 3.6+ and to install it we run from the Python environment
We’ll also need to build a server; in this case, we’ll use Uvicorn [vii] which we install
Let’s try a simple Python code to see if we can create an API
When you run it, Uvicorn server will be built that gives you access from your browser to http://localhost:8000/
Finally, we could apply the prediction receiving as parameter the URL of some of the images, which we would invoke for example with
Here, the code from Simon Willison⁷ as a reference of complete deployment (remember we need to take model.pkl file in deployment environment)

Note: This code is displayed as a guide and is taken directly from the course mentioned above. It is not the scope of this article to explain it step by step or to validate it. In general, the code receives from the request as parameter the URL of the image, opens it, makes the prediction, and returns a JSON with the probabilities of each category. You can consult Simon Wilson complete code, thanks him.
We have seen how to create our own set of images from the Google search engine, or how to manipulate images from a server to unify them to our client can label them.

We have developed a resnet34 neural net obtaining very good initial results, better after tuning the learning rate, and excellent final results after cleaning the training images that can generate confusion or be duplicate.
Finally, we have seen a superficial guide on how to deploy the model to make predictions of new cases.
All this through fast.ai for Pytorch, in few and short lines of code.
Once we remember that this article is inspired by the course https://course.fast.ai lesson 2, on which we have carried out our tests, and from which we take the basis for our real case.
I hope this article was useful for you, I will be grateful for comments and reports if something could be doing better.
[1] Into fast.ai course referred, this technique is inspired by: Francisco Ingham and Jeremy Howard / [Adrian Rosebrock]

[*] Lately, it has happened to me that confusion matrices with more than two class see strangely and erroneously, apparently is a subject of the version of matplotlib, so I decided to include it anyway.
[5] Uvicorn is a lightning-fast ASGI server, built on uvloop and httptools.
[6] Starlette is a lightweight ASGI framework/toolkit, which is ideal for building high performance asyncio services
[7] Simon Willison make the structure of this code
Machine learning enthusiast and research at Kreilabs Uruguay. My profile: https://gnaya73.glitch.me/
